document: Software Evolution and Maintenance Models – Chapter 3 of Tripathy & Naik’s book

questions.question: The traditional Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) has only one phase that includes both development and maintenance activities.
In the SDLC, maintenance is typically performed for roughly two–thirds of a product’s life‑span.
Software maintenance always requires that all changes be made to source code before any documentation is updated.
The Quick Fix Model proposes that the necessary changes are applied directly to the source code and then to the accompanying documentation.
In the Iterative Enhancement Model, changes begin at the lowest‑level artifacts such as test case libraries.
The Full Reuse Model requires identifying components of an old system that are candidates for reuse before any modification takes place.
The staged model for CSS (Commercial Software Systems) includes a phase called ‘Phase out’ where the system is wrapped and then permanently shut down.
In the FLOSS staged model, there is no possibility of transitioning from the ‘Servicing’ stage back to the ‘Evolution’ stage.
The Change Mini‑Cycle model was introduced to detail how a change may introduce new requirements or alter existing ones.
IEEE/EIA 1219 defines seven phases in its maintenance process, the last of which is ‘Delivery’.
In IEEE/EIA 1219, the phase following ‘System Test’ is named ‘Acceptance Test’.
Implementation in IEEE/EIA 1219 involves only writing new code, not performing unit testing.
ISO/IEC 14764 describes maintenance as an iterative process for managing and executing software maintenance activities.
The ISO/IEC 14764 maintenance process includes a ‘Migration’ activity that is responsible for designing the migration steps.
Software Configuration Management (SCM) manages only the source code and executable binaries, but not documentation or hardware.
A benefit of effective SCMM is that it reduces confusion during configuration changes.
The spectrum of functionality for SCM includes the categories ‘product’, ‘tool’ and ‘process’.
A change request (CR) workflow is designed to uniquely identify, describe and track each change.
